objects.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
objects.description: Malware may encrypt files stored on the system to prevent user access until a ransom is paid and/or to interrupt system availability. The encryption process usually iterates over all letter drives in the system (except for CD drives) and then recursively encrypts all files with specific suffixes.

objects.name: Automated Exfiltration
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data via automated processing or scripting.

objects.name: Setuid and Setgid
objects.description: Malware may take advantage of setuid or setgid bits in Linux or macOS applications to elevate privilege or for persistence.

objects.name: Data from Removable Media
objects.description: Malware collects from removable media connected to the compromised system.

objects.name: Service Stop
objects.description: Malware may stop or disable services on a system.

objects.name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
objects.description: Malware may use a custom cryptographic protocol to hide command and control communications.

objects.name: Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data via a different network medium than the command and control channel.

objects.name: Indicator Removal on Host
objects.description: Malware may delete artifacts on the infected system.

objects.name: Alternative Installation Location
objects.description: Malware may install itself not as a file on the hard drive.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Stores itself in memory.
x_mitre_methods.name: Fileless Malware

x_mitre_methods.definition: Stores itself in the Windows registry.
x_mitre_methods.name: Registry Install

objects.name: Network Share Discovery
objects.description: Malware may discover and/or scan shared network drives.

objects.name: Memory Dump Evasion
objects.description: Malware hinders retrieval and/or discovery of the contents of the physical memory of the system on which the malware instance is executing [[1]](#1).

x_mitre_methods.definition: Encrypt the executing malware instance code in memory.
x_mitre_methods.name: Code Encryption in Memory

x_mitre_methods.definition: Erase PE header from memory.
x_mitre_methods.name: Erase the PE header

x_mitre_methods.definition: Hide arbitrary segments of virtual memory.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hide virtual memory

x_mitre_methods.definition: Set the SizeOfImage field of PEB.LoaderData to be huge.
x_mitre_methods.name: SizeOfImage

x_mitre_methods.definition: Erase or corrupt specific file parts to prevent rebuilding (header, packer stub, etc.).
x_mitre_methods.name: Tampering

x_mitre_methods.definition: Encrypt blocks of code individually and decrypt temporarily only upon execution.
x_mitre_methods.name: Guard Pages

x_mitre_methods.definition: Resolve API addresses before each use to prevent complete dumping.
x_mitre_methods.name: On-the-Fly APIs

x_mitre_methods.definition: API behavior can be altered to prevent memory dumps. For example, inaccurate data can be reported when the contents of the physical memory of the system on which the malware instance is executing is retrieved. See [Hooking](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/anti-behavioral-analysis/hooking.md).
x_mitre_methods.name: Feed Misinformation

x_mitre_methods.definition: flow opcodes (e.g., jumps, loops) are removed and emulated (or decrypted) by the packer during execution, resulting in incorrect dumps. [[4]](#4)
x_mitre_methods.name: Flow Opcode Obstruction

objects.name: Credentials in Web Browsers
objects.description: Malware may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser.

objects.name: Executable Code Optimization
objects.description: Code is optimized, making it harder to statically analyze.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Relative operands of jumps and calls into are made absolute (better compression). May confuse some basic block detection algorithms.
x_mitre_methods.name: Jump/Call Absolute Address

x_mitre_methods.definition: Minification is 'the process of removing all unnecessary characters from source code without changing its functionality.' [[1]](#1) A simple example is when all the unnecessary whitespace and comments are removed. Minification is distinguished from compression in that it neither adds to nor changes the code seen by the interpreter. Minification is often used for malware written in interpreted languages, such as JavaScript, PHP, or Python. Legitimate code that is transmitted many times a second, such as JavaScript on websites, often uses minification to simply reduce the number of bytes transmitted.
x_mitre_methods.name: Minification

objects.name: Binary Padding
objects.description: Malware is padded to increase its size beyond what security tools can handle or to change its hash.

objects.name: Distributed Component Object Model
objects.description: Malware may use Windows Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) for lateral movement.

objects.name: Scripting
objects.description: Malware may use scripts to bypass process monitoring mechanisms (e.g., VBScript). Malicious scripts can be embedded in Microsoft Office documents, which will execute when the document is opened or when the user enables and runs the macro.

objects.name: Conditional Execution
objects.description: Malware checks system environment conditions or characteristics to determine execution path. For example, malware may not run or be dormant unless system conditions are right, or file that is dropped may vary according to execution environment. Conditional execution happens autonomously, not because of an attacker's command.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware terminates its execution based on a trigger condition or value (or because it has completed).
x_mitre_methods.name: Suicide Exit

objects.name: Secondary CPU Execution (THEORETICAL)
objects.description: Executes some or all of the code of the malware instance on a secondary, non-CPU processor (e.g., graphics processing unit (GPU)). This behavior is not included in the MBC because no real world examples have been found.

objects.name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
objects.description: Malware accesses files that contain sensitive data or credentials (e.g., passwords). Access of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency wallets also fall under this behavior.

objects.name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
objects.description: Malware may exploit a software vulnerability in defensive security software to avoid detection.

objects.name: Dynamic Data Exchange
objects.description: Malware may use Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) to execute commands.

objects.name: Disabling Security Tools
objects.description: Malware may disable security tools to avoid detection. Security tools include OS security features and updating tools, anti-virus (AV) tools, firewalls, tool components providing security related logging and/or reporting, and Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) related capabilities.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Bypasses or disables kernel patch protection mechanisms such as Windows' PatchGuard, enabling the malware instance to operate at the same level as the operating system kernel and kernel mode drivers (KMD).
x_mitre_methods.name: Disable Kernel Patch Protection

x_mitre_methods.definition: Disables system file overwrite protection mechanisms such as Windows file protection, thereby enabling system files to be modified or replaced.
x_mitre_methods.name: Disable System File Overwrite Protection

x_mitre_methods.definition: Security products may hook APIs to monitor the behavior of malware. To avoid being found, malware may load DLLs in memory and overwrite their bytes.
x_mitre_methods.name: Unhook APIs

objects.name: Web Service
objects.description: Malware may use existing external Web services for relaying C2 commands.

objects.name: Automated Collection
objects.description: Malware uses automated techniques for collecting system data.

objects.name: Executable Code Obfuscation
objects.description: Executable code can be obfuscated to hinder disassembly and static code analysis. This behavior is specific to a malware sample's executable code (data and text sections).

x_mitre_methods.definition: Instead of storing function names in the Import Address Table (IAT) and calling GetProcAddress, a DLL is loaded and the name of each of its exports is hashed until it matches a specific hash. Manual symbol resolution is then used to access and execute the exported function. This method is often used by shellcode because it reduces the size of each import from a human-readable string to a sequence of four bytes. The Method is also known as "Imports by Hash" and "GET_APIS_WITH_CRC." [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: API Hashing

x_mitre_methods.definition:
Insert code to impede disassembly.
   * *Dead Code Insertion*: Include "dead" code with no real functionality.
   * *Fake Code Insertion*: Add fake code similar to known packers or known goods to fool identification. Can confuse some automated unpackers.
   * *Jump Insertion*: Insert jumps to make analysis visually harder.
   * *Thunk Code Insertion*: Variation on Jump Insertion. Used by some compilers for user-generated functions.
   * *Junk Code Insertion*: Insert dummy code between relevant opcodes. Can make signature writing more complex.
x_mitre_methods.name: Code Insertion

x_mitre_methods.definition: Obfuscate data values through indirection of local or global variables. For example, the instruction *if (a == 0) do x* can be obfuscated by setting a global variable, *Z*, to zero and using it in the instruction: *if (a==Z) do x*.  [NEEDS REVIEW]
x_mitre_methods.name: Data Value Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Obfuscate the entry point of the malware executable.
x_mitre_methods.name: Entry Point Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Encrypt blocks of code individually and decrypt temporarily only upon execution.
x_mitre_methods.name: Guard Pages

x_mitre_methods.definition: Obfuscate the import address table.
x_mitre_methods.name: Import Address Table Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Store and load imports with a compact import table format. Each DLL needed by the executable is mentioned in the IAT, but only one function from each/most is imported; the rest are imported via GetProcAddress calls.
x_mitre_methods.name: Import Compression

x_mitre_methods.definition: Jump after the first byte of an instruction to confuse disassembler.
x_mitre_methods.name: Instruction Overlap

x_mitre_methods.definition: Split code into sections that may be rearranged and are connected by unconditional jumps.
x_mitre_methods.name: Interleaving Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Merge all sections resulting in just one entry in the sections table to make readability more difficult. May affect some detection signatures if written to be section dependent.
x_mitre_methods.name: Merged Code Sections

x_mitre_methods.definition: Build and decrypt strings on the stack at each use, then discard to avoid obvious references.
x_mitre_methods.name: Stack Strings

x_mitre_methods.definition: Remove or rename symbolic information commonly inserted by compilers for debugging purposes.
x_mitre_methods.name: Symbol Obfuscation

objects.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get information about peripheral devices.

objects.name: Kernel Modules and Extensions
objects.description: Malware may use loadable kernel modules to persist on a system.

objects.name: Prevent Concurrent Execution
objects.description: To avoid running multiple instances of itself, malware may check a system to see if it is already running.

objects.name: Data Encrypted
objects.description: Malware may obfuscate data via encryption or encoding before exfiltration.

objects.name: Regsvr32
objects.description: Malware may use the Regsvr32.exe command-line program to execute binary code.

objects.name: .bash_profile and .bashrc
objects.description: Malware may insert code into these Linux and macOS files to gain persistence.

objects.name: Location Tracking
objects.description: Malware tracks a system's physical location.

objects.name: PowerShell
objects.description: Malware may use PowerShell to execute code on a system.

objects.name: Emulator Evasion
objects.description: Behaviors that obstruct analysis in an emulator.

objects.name: File and Directory Discovery
objects.description: Malware may enumerate files and/or directories.

objects.name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
objects.description: Malware may check for the presence or a virtual machine or sandbox to avoid detection.

objects.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
objects.description: Malware may make a system unavailable, for example, by locking a user out of a system. The ATT&CK technique, [Lock User Out of Device](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1446/), pertains to the Android platform; the technique [Endpoint Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/) is applicable to other platforms.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Locks user out of a system.
x_mitre_methods.name: User Lock Out

objects.name: Credentials in Registry
objects.description: Malware may query the Registry looking for credentials and passwords.

objects.name: Office Application Startup
objects.description: Malware may use a mechanism with Office for persistence when an Office-based application is started.

objects.name: NTFS File Attributes
objects.description: Malware may store malicious data in file attribute metadata.

objects.name: Data from Local System
objects.description: Malware collects sensitive data from local system sources.

objects.name: Connection Proxy
objects.description: Malware may use a connection proxy to manage command and control communications.

objects.name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
objects.description: Malware may generate advertising revenue by generating clicks of advertising links. The ATT&CK technique, [Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1472/), pertains only to mobile platform, but the behavior is applicable to other platforms as well.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware alters DNS server settings to route to a rogue DNS server: when the user clicks on a search result link displayed through a search engine query, malware re-routes the user to different website. Instead of going to the requested site, the user is taken to an alternate website such that the click triggers payment to the threat actor. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Click Hijacking

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware injects ad windows onto websites the user is views. [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Advertisement Replacement Fraud

objects.name: Remote System Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get a list of network-accessible systems (by IP address or hostname).

objects.name: Self Discovery
objects.description: Malware may gather information about itself, such as its filename or size on disk.

objects.name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
objects.description: Android malware may try to get details of on-board network interfaces through the java.net.NetworkInterface class.

objects.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning
objects.description: Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) and NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) are Microsoft Windows components that serve as alternate methods of host identification. Malware may spoof an authoritative source, poisoning the service.

objects.name: Query Registry
objects.description: Malware may gather information from the Windows registry.

objects.name: Polymorphic Code
objects.description: Polymorphic code, a file with the same functionality but different execution, is created, often on the fly, making it difficult to detect. This behavior includes metamorphic code where the code is changed (not just executed differently), but with the behavior the same. Polymorphic Code behavior is typically identified through analysis of related samples.

x_mitre_methods.definition: A packer stub can generate polymorphic code.
x_mitre_methods.name: Packer Stub

objects.name: Redundant Access
objects.description: Malware may use more than one type of access for persistence and to avoid detection.

objects.name: Boot Sector Modification
objects.description: The boot sectors of a hard drive are modified (e.g., Master Boot Record (MBR)). ATT&CK associates bootkits with the Persistence. See ATT&CK: [**Bootkit**](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1067/).

objects.name: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: Malware may connect to a remote system over Remote Desktop Protocol.

objects.name: Microphone or Camera Capture
objects.description: Malware records activities using the device microphone and/or camera.

objects.name: User Interaction
objects.description: Malware may include code that relies on specific actions by a user to execute. Note that this MBC behavior differs from [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) in that it does do not include direct code execution (user action for *initial* execution) - MBE does not encompass ATT&CK's Initial Access Tactic.

objects.name: Remote Commands
objects.description: Malware may provide an attacker with explicit commands. This behavior differs from the [Remote Access](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/impact/remote-access.md) behavior under the [Impact](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/tree/master/impact) objective in that *Impact: Remote Access* is potentially much broader and may include full remote access.

objects.name: Data Obfuscation
objects.description: Malware hides its command and control information.

objects.name: Account Manipulation
objects.description: Malware may manipulate accounts to maintain access to credentials or permission levels.

objects.name: File System Permissions Weakness
objects.description: Malware may exploit a software vulnerability to escalate privileges.

objects.name: New Service
objects.description: Malware may install a new service to gain persistence or to escalate privileges (from administrator to SYSTEM).

objects.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data via the command and control channel.

objects.name: Code Signing
objects.description: Malware code is digitally signed to appear as legitimate software.

objects.name: Inhibit System Recovery
objects.description: Malware may delete OS data and turn off services designed to provide system recovery.

objects.name: Image File Execution Options Injection
objects.description: Malware may use Image File Execution Options to launch a process.

objects.name: Emulator Detection
objects.description: Detects whether the malware instance is being executed inside an emulator. If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Checks whether particular files (e.g., QEMU files) exist.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check for Emulator-related Files

x_mitre_methods.definition: Checks for WINE via the `get_wine_version` function from WINE's `ntdll.dll`.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check for WINE Version

x_mitre_methods.definition: Emulators register artifacts in the registry, which can be detected by malware. For example, installation of QEMU results in the registry key: *HARDWARE\DEVICEMAP\Scsi\Scsi Port 0\Scsi Bus 0\Target Id 0\Logical Unit Id 0* with value=*Identifier* and data=*QEMU*, or registry key: *HARDWARE\Description\System* with value=*SystemBiosVersion* and data=*QEMU*. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Emulator-related Registry Keys

x_mitre_methods.definition: Some emulated systems fail to handle some network communications; such failures will indicate the emulated environment.
x_mitre_methods.name: Failed Network Connections

objects.name: Exploit Kit Behavior
objects.description: An Exploit Kit is a toolkit that exploits vulnerabilities in software to deliver malicious payloads (malware).

objects.name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
objects.description: Malware may use a standard cryptographic protocol to conceal command and control traffic or other data.

objects.name: Domain Name Generation
objects.description: Malware generates the domain name of the command and control server to which it connects. Access to on the fly domains enables C2 to operate as domains and IP addresses are blocked. The algorithm can be complicated in more advanced bots; understanding the details so that names can be predicted can be useful in mitigation and response.

objects.name: Local Job Scheduling
objects.description: Malware may execute a program or script via local job scheduling (e.g., cron job) for execution or persistence purposes.

objects.name: System Firmware
objects.description: Malware may overwrite the system firmware with malicious firmware that is difficult to detect and/or enables persistence.

objects.name: Data Compressed
objects.description: Malware may compress data prior to exfiltration.

objects.name: System Information Discovery
objects.description: Malware may attempt to get detailed information about the system.

objects.name: Browser Extensions
objects.description: Malware may add functionality to browsers or customize them with extensions or plugins.

objects.name: Uncommonly Used Port
objects.description: Malware may use an uncommon port to bypass poorly configured boundary controllers.

objects.name: Resource Hijacking
objects.description: Uses system resources for other purposes; as a result, the system may not be available for intended uses.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Consume system resources for the purpose of password cracking.
x_mitre_methods.name: Password Cracking

x_mitre_methods.definition: Consume system resources to mine for cryptocurrency (e.g., Bitcoin, Litecoin, etc.).
x_mitre_methods.name: Cryptojacking

objects.name: Clipboard Data
objects.description: Malware collects data stored in the Windows clipboard.

objects.name: Commonly Used Port
objects.description: Malware may use a common port to avoid detection of command and control activity.

objects.name: Rundll32
objects.description: Malware may use the Rundll32.exe program to execute binary code.

objects.name: Input Capture
objects.description: Malware captures user input.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Mouse events are captured.
x_mitre_methods.name: Mouse Events

x_mitre_methods.definition: Keyboard events are captured.
x_mitre_methods.name: Keyboard Events

objects.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
objects.description: This behavior is the counterpart to [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/defense-evasion/obfuscate-files.md), which is used to hide artifacts of an intrusion.

objects.name: Disk Content Wipe
objects.description: The contents of a storage device are partially or completely wiped. Rather than selecting individual files (see [Data Destruction](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/tree/master/impact/data-destruction.md)), arbitrary data is destroyed.

objects.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
objects.description: Malware may place a malicious DLL with the same name as a legitimate, but ambiguously specified, DLL in a location that Windows searches before the legitimate DLL (called a binary planting attack).

objects.name: Network Service Scanning
objects.description: Malware may try to a listing of services running on remotes hosts.

objects.name: Dynamic Analysis Evasion
objects.description: Malware may obstruct dynamic analysis in a sandbox, emulator, or virtual machine.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Overloads a sandbox by generating a flood of meaningless behavioral data. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Data Flood

x_mitre_methods.definition: Inclusion of a demo binary/mode that is executed when token is absent or not enough privileged.
x_mitre_methods.name: Demo Mode

x_mitre_methods.definition: Original file is written to disk then executed. May confuse some sandboxes, especially if the dropped executable must be provided specific arguments and the original dropper is not associated with the drop file(s).
x_mitre_methods.name: Drop Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Encode a file on disk, such as an implant's config file.
x_mitre_methods.name: Encode File

x_mitre_methods.definition: execution happens when a particular file or directory is accessed, often through hooking certain API calls such as CreateFileA and CreateFileW.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hook File System

x_mitre_methods.definition: modification of interrupt vector or descriptor tables.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hook Interrupt

x_mitre_methods.definition: Creates an illusion; makes the analyst think something happened when it didn't.
x_mitre_methods.name: Illusion

objects.name: Security Software Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get a listing of security software or defensive tools installed on the system. Note that security software aims to *detect/mitigate* malware on a system whereas analysis tools (see [Analysis Tool Discovery](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/discovery/analysis-tool-discover.md)) are used to *analyze* malware.

objects.name: Bypass User Account Control
objects.description: Malware bypasses Windows User Account Control.

objects.name: Execution through API
objects.description: Malware may execute via the Windows application programming interface (API).

objects.name: Supply Chain Compromise
objects.description: The supply chain may be compromised to enable initial malware infection. Malware-related methods are listed below to supplement the information available defined in ATT&CK: [**Supply Chain Compromise**](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195/).

x_mitre_methods.definition: Abusing enterprise certificates enables malware to exploit private APIs and infect a wide range of users (see *Exploit Private APIs* below).
x_mitre_methods.name: Abuse Enterprise Certificates

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware can exploit private APIs to infect jailbroken and non-jailbroken iOS devices. Research shows that over 100 apps in the App Store have abused private APIs and bypassed Apples strict code review.
x_mitre_methods.name: Exploit Private APIs

objects.name: Malicious Network Driver
objects.description: Malicious network drivers can be installed on several machines on a network via an exploited server with high uptime. Once the drivers are installed on the host machines, they can re-infect the server if it is restarted (persistence), can infect other machines on the network (lateral movement), and can redirect traffic on the network.

objects.name: Indicator Blocking
objects.description: Malware blocks indicators or events that would indicate malicious activity. Methods relevant to the malware domain are below.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware captures the message body of incoming SMS messages and aborts displaying messages that meets a certain criteria.
x_mitre_methods.name: Remove SMS Warning Messages

objects.name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data via a physical medium or device (e.g., USB drive).

objects.name: System Network Connections Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get a listing of network connections to/from the compromised system.

objects.name: C2 Communication
objects.description: All command and control malware use client/server communication. The methods listed below can be used to capture explicit communication details. Remote file copy behavior is captured separately, as is done in ATT&CK - see [Remote File Copy](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/command-and-control/remote-file-copy.md).

objects.name: Hidden Files and Directories
objects.description: Malware may hide files and folders to avoid detection and/or to persist on the system. See potential methods below.

objects.name: Launch Daemon
objects.description: Malware may install a new MacOS launch daemon that can be configured to execute at startup.

objects.name: SMTP Connection Discovery
objects.description: Malware may test whether an outgoing SMTP connection can be made from the system on which the malware instance is executing to some SMTP server, by sending a test SMTP transaction.

objects.name: Modify Registry
objects.description: Malware may make changes to the Windows Registry to hide execution or to persist on the system (note that ATT&CK does not extend this behavior to the Persistence objective).

objects.name: Capture SMS Messages
objects.description: Malware captures data sent via SMS (e.g., authentication credentials).

objects.name: Component Firmware
objects.description: Malware may overwrite the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other firmware. [[1]](#1). Methods related to malware (extending ATT&CK's definitions) are below.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Cisco routers can have their firmware images modified in order to maliciously infect and persist on end-user machines in a network. This is accomplished by using default or acquired credentials to gain access to a router and to install a backdoor. The implant resides within a modified Cisco IOS image and, when loaded, maintains its persistence in the environment, even after a system reboot. However, any further modules loaded by the attacker will only exist in the router's volatile memory and will not be available for use after reboot. Known affected hardware includes Cisco routers 1841, 2811, and 3825.
x_mitre_methods.name: Router Firmware

objects.name: Process Hollowing
objects.description: Instead of performing [Process Injection](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/defense-evasion/process-inject.md), malware may unmap (hollows out) legitimate code from the target process's memory (e.g., svchost.exe) and overwrite the memory space with a malicious code.

objects.name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
objects.description: Malware may use a custom command and control protocol instead of encapsulating commands and data in a [Standard Application Layer Protocol](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/tree/master/command-and-control/std-protocol.md).

objects.name: System Service Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get information about registered services.

objects.name: Data Staged
objects.description: Malware stages collected data prior to [Exfiltration](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/tree/master/exfiltration).

objects.name: System Time Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get the system time or time zone for a system.

objects.name: File Deletion
objects.description: Malware may remove dropped files or tools to avoid detection.

objects.name: Parent PID Spoofing
objects.description: Malware may spoof the parent process identifier (PPID) of a new process to evade process-monitoring defenses or to elevate privileges.

objects.name: Windows Management Instrumentation
objects.description: Malware may use Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to perform a variety of operations.

objects.name: File System Logical Offsets
objects.description: Malware may bypass Windows file access controls by analyzing file system data structures.

objects.name: Virtual Machine Detection
objects.description: Detects whether the malware instance is being executed in a virtual machine (VM), such as VMWare. If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Virtual machines create files on the file system (e.g., VMware creates files in the installation directory C:\Program Files\VMware\VMware Tools). Malware can check the different folders to find virtual machine artifacts (e.g., Virtualbox has the artifact VBoxMouse.sys). [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check File and Directory Artifacts

x_mitre_methods.definition: VMware leaves many artifacts in memory. Some are critical processor structures, which, because they are either moved or changed on a virtual machine, leave recognizable footprints. Malware can search through physical memory for the strings VMware, commonly used to detect memory artifacts. [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Memory Artifacts

x_mitre_methods.definition: Virtual machines often include specific named system objects by default, such as Windows device drivers, which can be detected by testing for specific strings, whether found in the Windows registry or other places.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Named System Objects

x_mitre_methods.definition: The VMware Tools use processes like VMwareServices.exe or VMwareTray.exe, to perform actions on the virtual environment. Malware can list the process and searches for the VMware string. Process related to Virtualbox can be detected by malware by query the process list. [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Processes

x_mitre_methods.definition: Virtual machines register artifacts in the registry, which can be detected by malware. For example, a search for "VMware" or "VBOX" in the registry might reveal keys that include information about a virtual hard drive, adapters, running services, or virtual mouse. [[2]](#2) Example registry key value artifacts include "HARDWARE\Description\System (SystemBiosVersion) (VBOX)" and "SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Control\SystemInformation (SystemManufacturer) (VMWARE)"; example registry key artifacts include "SOFTWARE\VMware, Inc.\VMware Tools (VMWARE)" and "SOFTWARE\Oracle\VirtualBox Guest Additions (VBOX)". [[5]](#5)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Registry Keys

x_mitre_methods.definition: VMwareService.exe runs the VMware Tools Service as a child of services.exe. It can be identified by listing services. [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Running Services

x_mitre_methods.definition: The presence of virtual devices can indicate a virtualized environment (e.g., "\\.\VBoxTrayIPC"). [[5]](#5)
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Virtual Devices

x_mitre_methods.definition:
Malware may check windows for VM-related characteristics such as:
	* *Window size*: tiny window size may indicate a VM.
	* *Unique windows*: may check for the presence of known windows from analysis tools running in a VM.
	* *Title bars*: may inject malicious code to svchost.exe to check all open window title bar text to a list of strings indicating virtualized environment.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Windows

x_mitre_methods.definition: Virtual machines offer guest additions that can be installed to add functionality such as clipboard sharing. Detecting the process responsible for these tasks, via its name or other methods, is a technique employed by malware for detecting whether it is being executed in a virtual machine.
x_mitre_methods.name: Guest Process Testing

x_mitre_methods.definition: In three browser families, it is possible to extract the frequency of the Windows performance counter frequency, using standard HTML and Javascript. This value can then be used to detect whether the code is being executed in a virtual machine, by detecting two specific frequencies commonly used in virtual but not physical machines.
x_mitre_methods.name: HTML5 Performance Object Check

x_mitre_methods.definition: Detects whether there is any "user" activity on the machine, such as the movement of the mouse cursor, non-default wallpaper, or recently opened Office files. If there is no human activity, the machine is suspected to be a virtualized machine and/or sandbox. Other items used to detect a user: mouse clicks (single/double), DialogBox, scrolling, color of background pixel, change in foreground window [[5]](#5).
x_mitre_methods.name: Human User Check

x_mitre_methods.definition:
Different aspects of the hardware are inspected to determine whether the machine has modern characteristics. A machine with substandard specifications indicates a virtual environment: 
   * *Total physical memory*: most modern machines have at leave 4 GB of memory. (GlobalMemoryStatusEx) [[5]](#5).
   * *Drive size*: most modern machines have at least 80 GB disks. May use DeviceloControl (IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO) or GetDiskFreeSpaceEx (TotalNumberOfBytes) [[5]](#5).
   * *USB drive*: checks whether there is a potential USB drive; if not a virtual environment is suspected.
   * *Printer*: checks whether there is a potential connected printer or default Windows printers; if not a virtual environment is suspected.
   * *Processor count*: checks number of processors; single CPU machines are suspect.
   * *Keyboard layout*
   * *Software*: checks whether software is relatively current.
x_mitre_methods.name: Modern Specs Check

x_mitre_methods.definition:
Malware may check for hardware characteristics unique to being virtualized, allowing the malware to detect the virtual environment. Items checked include:
   * *BIOS*: characteristics of the BIOS, such as version, can indicate virtualization.
   * *I/O Communication Port*: VMware uses virtual I/O ports for communication between the virtual machine and the host operating system to support functionality like copy and paste between the two systems. The port can be queried and compared with a magic number VMXh to identify the use of VMware.
   * *CPU Name*
   * *CPU Location*: When an Operating System is virtualized, the CPU is relocated. [[2]](#2)
   * *MAC Address*: VMware uses specific virtual MAC address that can be detected. The usual MAC address used started with the following numbers: "00:0C:29", "00:1C:14", "00:50:56", "00:05:69". Virtualbox uses specific virtual MAC address that can be detected by Malware. The usual MAC address used started with the following numbers: 08:00:27. [[2]](#2)
x_mitre_methods.name: Unique Hardware/Firmware Check

x_mitre_methods.definition:
The execution of certain x86 instructions will result in different values when executed inside of a VM instead of on bare metal. Accordingly, these can be used to detect the execution of the malware in a VM. [[2]](#2)
   * *SIDT (red pill)*: Red Pill is an anti-VM technique that executes the SIDT instruction to grab the value of the IDTR register. The virtual machine monitor must relocate the guest's IDTR to avoid conflict with the host's IDTR. Since the virtual machine monitor is not notified when the virtual machine runs the SIDT instruction, the IDTR for the virtual machine is returned.
   * *SGDT/SLDT (no pill)*: The No Pill technique relies on the fact that the LDT structure is assigned to a processor not an Operating System. The LDT location on a host machine will be zero and on a virtual machine will be non-zero.
   * *SMSW*
   * *STR*
   * *CPUID*: Checking the CPU ID found within the registry can provide information to system type.
   * *IN*
   * *RDTSC*
   * *VMCPUID*
   * *VPCEXT*
x_mitre_methods.name: x86 Instruction Testing

objects.name: Software Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to identify all software and applications installed on the device.

objects.name: Credentials in Files
objects.description: Malware may search local file system and remote file shares for files containing passwords.

objects.name: System Owner/User Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to identify the users of the system.

objects.name: Process Injection
objects.description: Malware may execute code in the address space of a separate process.

external_references.description: Ashkan Hosseini, *Ten Process Injection Techniques: A Technical Survey of Common and Trending Process Injection Techniques*, July 2017.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Injects code using the Shell_TRyaWnd technique.
x_mitre_methods.name: Shell_TrayWnd

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware creates a thread using CreateRemoteThread (or NtCreateThreadEx, RtlCreateUserThread) and LoadLibrary. The path to the malware's malicious dynamic-link library (DLL) is written in the virtual address space of another process; the malware ensures the remote process loads it by creating a remote thread in the target process. This is one of the most common process injection methods. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: CreateRemoteThread

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware copies its malicious code into an existing open process and causes it to execute via shellcode or by calling CreateRemoteThread (instead of passing the address of the LoadLibrary) [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: PE Injection

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware targets an existing thread of a process, avoiding noisy process or thread creations operations. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Thread Execution Hijacking

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware can leverage hooking functionality to have its malicious DLL loaded upon an event getting triggered in a specific thread, which is usually done by calling SetWindowsHookEx to install a hook routine into the hook chain. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: SetWindowsHooksEx

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may leverage Asynchronous Procedure Calls (APC) to force another thread to execute its code by attaching it to the APC Queue of the target thread (using QueueUserAPC / NtQueueApcThread); also called AtomBombing [[1]](#1), [[3]](#3).
x_mitre_methods.name: APC Injection

x_mitre_methods.definition: GetThreadContext / SetThreadContext [[3]](#3).
x_mitre_methods.name: RunPE

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may insert the location of its malicious library under a registry key (e.g., Appinit_DLL, AppCertDlls, IFEO) to have another process load its library. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Registry Modification

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may use shims to target an executable (shims are a way of hooking into APIs and targeting specific executables and are provided by Microsoft for backward compatibility, allowing developers to apply program fixes without rewriting code) [[1]](#1).
x_mitre_methods.name: Shims

objects.name: Sudo
objects.description: Malware may take advantage of the sudoers file in Linux or macOS for privilege escalation.

objects.name: Sandbox Detection
objects.description: Detects whether the malware instance is being executed inside an instrumented sandbox environment (e.g., Cuckoo Sandbox). If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Checks clipboard data which can be used to detect whether execution is inside a sandbox.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Clipboard Data

x_mitre_methods.definition: Sandboxes create files on the file system. Malware can check the different folders to find sandbox artifacts.
x_mitre_methods.name: Check Files

x_mitre_methods.definition: Detects whether there is any "user" activity on the machine, such as the movement of the mouse cursor, non-default wallpaper, or recently opened Office files. If there is no human activity, the machine is suspected to be a virtualized machine and/or sandbox. Other items used to detect a user: mouse clicks (single/double), DialogBox, scrolling, color of background pixel [[3]](#3).
x_mitre_methods.name: Human User Check

x_mitre_methods.definition: Testing for the name of a particular DLL that is known to be injected by a sandbox for API hooking is a common way of detecting sandbox environments. This can be achieved through the kernel32!GetModuleHandle API call and other means.
x_mitre_methods.name: Injected DLL Testing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Checking for a particular product key/ID associated with a sandbox environment (commonly associated with the Windows host OS used in the environment) can be used to detect whether a malware instance is being executed in a particular sandbox. This can be achieved through several means, including testing for the Key/ID in the Windows registry.
x_mitre_methods.name: Product Key/ID Testing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Sandboxes aren't used in the same manner as a typical user environment, so most of the time the screen resolution stays at the minimum 800x600 or lower. No one is actually working on a such small screen. Malware could potentially detect the screen resolution to determine if it's a user machine or a sandbox.
x_mitre_methods.name: Screen Resolution Testing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may check its own characteristics to determine whether it's running in a sandbox. For example, a malicious Office document might check its file name or VB project name.
x_mitre_methods.name: Self Check

x_mitre_methods.definition: Calling GetSystemTime or equiv and only executing code if the current date/hour/minute/second passes some check. Often this is for running only after or only until a specific date. This behavior can be mitigated in non-automated analysis environments.
x_mitre_methods.name: Timing/Date Checks

x_mitre_methods.definition: Comparing single GetTickCount with some value to see if system has been started at least *X* amount ago. This behavior can be mitigated in non-automated analysis environments.
x_mitre_methods.name: Timing/Uptime Check

objects.name: Install Additional Program
objects.description: Installs another, different program on the system. The additional program can be any secondary module; examples include backdoors, malicious drivers, kernel modules, and OS X Apps.

objects.name: Process Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get information about running processes.

objects.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
objects.description: Malware may make files or information difficult to discover or analyze by encoding, encrypting, or otherwise obfuscating the content. In addition, a malware sample itself can be encoded or encrypted (i.e., encoding/encryption is a code characteristic).

x_mitre_methods.definition:
* *Standard Encryption*: A standard algorithm, such as Rijndael/AES, DES, RC4, is used to encrypt an executable file. Encryption hinders static analysis of malware code. Also known as **Code Encryption in File**.
   * *Standard Encryption of Code*: A standard encryption algorithm is used to encrypt a file's executable code, but not necessarily the file's data. 
   * *Standard Encryption of Data*: A standard encryption algorithm is used to encrypt a file's data, but not necessarily the file's code. 
   * *Custom Encryption*: A custom algorithm is used to encrypt an executable file. Encryption hinders static analysis of malware code. Also known as **Code Encryption in File**.
   * *Custom Encryption of Code*: A custom encryption algorithm is used to encrypt a file's executable code, but not necessarily the file's data.
   * *Custom Encryption of Data*: A custom encryption algorithm is used to encrypt a file's data, but not necessarily the file's code.
x_mitre_methods.name: Encryption

objects.name: Modify Trusted Execution Environment
objects.description: Malware may run code in the Android Trusted Execution Environment.

objects.name: TimeStomp
objects.description: Malware may modify the timestamps of a file to mimic files in the same folder and avoid detection.

objects.name: Rootkit Behavior
objects.description: Behaviors of a rootkit: "A rootkit is a collection of computer software, typically malicious, designed to enable access to a computer or areas of its software that is not otherwise allowed and often masks its existence or the existence of other software.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Hides the usage of any kernel modules by the malware instance.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hide Kernel Modules

x_mitre_methods.definition: Hides any system services that the malware instance creates or injects itself into.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hide Services

x_mitre_methods.definition: Hides one or more threads that belong to the malware instance.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hide Threads

x_mitre_methods.definition: Hides the usage of userspace libraries by the malware instance.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hide Userspace Libraries

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents the API hooks installed by the malware instance from being removed.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent API Unhooking

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents access to the Windows registry, including to the entire registry and/or to particular registry keys/values.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent Registry Access

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevent Windows registry keys and/or values associated with the malware instance from being deleted from a system.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent Registry Deletion

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents access to the file system, including to specific files and/or directories associated with the malware instance.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent File Access

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents files and/or directories associated with the malware instance from being deleted from a system.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent File Deletion

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents access to system memory where the malware instance may be storing code or data.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent Memory Access

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents other software from hooking native system APIs.
x_mitre_methods.name: Prevent Native API Hooking

objects.name: Execution through Module Load
objects.description: Malware may use the Windows module loader to execute code on a system.

objects.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
objects.description: Malware may exploit a vulnerability in a program, service, or operating system.

objects.name: Access Call Log
objects.description: Malware gathers call log data.

objects.name: Executable Code Virtualization
objects.description: Original executable code is virtualized by translating the code into a special format that only a special virtual machine (VM) can run; the VM uses a customized virtual instruction set. A "stub" function calls the VM when the code is run. Virtualized code makes static analysis and reverse engineering more difficult; dumped code wont run without the VM.

x_mitre_methods.definition: multiple virtual machines with different architectures (CISC, RISC, etc.) can be used inside of a single executable in order to make reverse engineering even more difficult.
x_mitre_methods.name: Multiple VMs

objects.name: Software Packing
objects.description: This code characteristic - Software Packing - can make static and behavioral analysis difficult and includes packing with a software protectors, such as Themida and Armadillo [[1]](#1). Methods related to anti-analysis are below.

external_references.description: Jiang Ming et al, Towards Paving the Way for Large-Scale Windows Malware Analysis: Generic Binary Unpacking with Orders-of-Magnitude Performance Boost, October 2018,

x_mitre_methods.definition: the malware is packed by one packer, the result is packed, etc.
x_mitre_methods.name: Nested Packing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a standard algorithm, such as UPX or LZMA, to compress an executable file.
x_mitre_methods.name: Standard Compression

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a standard algorithm to compress the opcode mnemonics.
x_mitre_methods.name: Standard Compression of Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a standard algorithm to compress strings and variables (executable file data).
x_mitre_methods.name: Standard Compression of Data

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a custom algorithm to compress an executable file.
x_mitre_methods.name: Custom Compression

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a custom algorithm to compress opcode mnemonics.
x_mitre_methods.name: Custom Compression of Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Uses a custom algorithm to compress strings and variables (executable file data).
x_mitre_methods.name: Custom Compression of Data

objects.name: Masquerading
objects.description: Malware may change the name or location of files to avoid detection.

objects.name: Send Email
objects.description: Sends an email message from the system on which the malware is executing to one or more recipients, mostly commonly for the purpose of spamming or for distributing a malicious attachment or URL (malspamming).

objects.name: Execution Guardrails
objects.description: Malware may use execution guardrails (environmental conditions) to constrain execution. This behavior is related to the [Evade Dynamic Analysis](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/tree/master/anti-behavioral-analysis/evade-dynamic-analysis.md) behavior that obstructs dynamic analysis in a sandbox, emulator, or virtual machine.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Parts of the code and/or data is encrypted or otherwise relies on data external to the file itself. For example, malware that contains code that is encrypted with a key that is downloaded from a server; malware that only runs if certain other software is installed on the system. Also see Environmental Keys Method.
x_mitre_methods.name: Deposited Keys

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware reads certain attributes of the system (BIOS version string, hostname, MAC address, etc.) and encrypts/decrypts portions of its code or data using those attributes as input, thus preventing itself from being run on an unintended system (e.g., sandbox, emulator, etc.). Also see Deposited Keys Method.
x_mitre_methods.name: Environmental Keys

x_mitre_methods.definition: This Windows API call is used to get the GUID on a system drive. Malware compares it to a previous (targeted) GUID value and only executes maliciously if they match. This behavior can be mitigated in non-automated analysis environments.
x_mitre_methods.name: GetVolumeInformation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Compare a previously computed host fingerprint(e.g., based on installed applications) to the current system's to determine if the malware instance is still executing on the same system. If not, execution stops, making debugging or sandbox analysis more difficult.
x_mitre_methods.name: Host Fingerprint Check

x_mitre_methods.definition: Code and/or data is encrypted until the underlying system satisfies a preselected condition unknown to the analyst (this is a form of Deposited Keys).
x_mitre_methods.name: Secure Triggers

x_mitre_methods.definition: Presence check to allow the program to run (ex: dongle, CD/DVD, key, file, network, etc.). If the token is specific to a hardware element (ex: disk, OS, CPU, NIC MAC, etc.), it is considered fingerprinting.
x_mitre_methods.name: Token Check

objects.name: Account Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get names of local system or domain accounts.

objects.name: File Permissions Modification
objects.description: Malware may modify file permissions to evade detection.

objects.name: Debugger Detection
objects.description: Malware detects whether it's being executed inside a debugger. If so, conditional execution selects a benign execution path.

external_references.description: Alexander Antukh, "Anti-debugging Techniques Cheat Sheet," 19 January 2015.
Joshua Cannell, Malwarebytes Labs, "Five Anti-Analysis Tricks that sometimes Fool Analysts," 31 March 2016.
Atif Mushtaq, FireEye, "The Dead Giveaways of VM-Aware Malware," 27 January 2011.
Nicolas Falliere, Symantec, "Windows Anti-Debug Reference," 11 September 2007.

x_mitre_methods.definition: module bounds based [[7]](#7)
x_mitre_methods.name: API Hook Detection

x_mitre_methods.definition: The kernel32!CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent function calls NtQueryInformationProcess with ProcessInformationClass parameter set to 7 (ProcessDebugPort constant).
x_mitre_methods.name: CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent

x_mitre_methods.definition: (NtClose); If an invalid handle is passed to the CloseHandle function and a debugger is present, then an EXCEPTION_INVALID_HANDLE (0xC0000008) exception will be raised. [[7]](#7)
x_mitre_methods.name: CloseHandle

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may detect a debugger by its artifact (window title, device driver, exports, etc.).
x_mitre_methods.name: Debugger Artifacts

x_mitre_methods.definition: (SEH/GetThreadContext); Debug registers will indicate the presence of a debugger. See [[7]](#7) for details.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hardware Breakpoints

x_mitre_methods.definition: If int 0x2d is mishandled by the debugger, it can cause a single-byte instruction to be inadvertently skipped, which can be detected by malware.
x_mitre_methods.name: Interrupt 0x2d

x_mitre_methods.definition: The kernel32!IsDebuggerPresent API function call checks the PEB BeingDebugged flag to see if the calling process is being debugged. It returns 1 if the process is being debugged, 0 otherwise. This is one of the most common ways of debugger detection.
x_mitre_methods.name: IsDebuggerPresent

x_mitre_methods.definition: (PAGE_GUARD); Guard pages trigger an exception the first time they are accessed and can be used to detect a debugger. See [[7]](#7) for details.
x_mitre_methods.name: Memory Breakpoints

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may spawn a monitoring thread to detect tampering, breakpoints, etc.
x_mitre_methods.name: Monitoring Thread

x_mitre_methods.definition: Calling NtQueryInformationProcess with its ProcessInformationClass parameter set to 0x07 (ProcessDebugPort constant) will cause the system to set ProcessInformation to -1 if the process is being debugged. Calling with ProcessInformationClass set to 0x0E (ProcessDebugFlags) or 0x11 (ProcessDebugObject) are used similarly. Testing "ProcessDebugPort" is equivalent to using the kernel32!CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent API call (see next method).
x_mitre_methods.name: NtQueryInformationProcess

x_mitre_methods.definition: The ObjectTypeInformation and ObjectAllTypesInformation flags are checked for debugger detection.
x_mitre_methods.name: NtQueryObject

x_mitre_methods.definition: Calling this API with a fake class length or thread handle can indicate whether it is hooked. After calling NtSetInformationThread properly, the HideThreadFromDebugger flag is checked with the NtQueryInformationThread API. [[7]](#7)
x_mitre_methods.name: NtSetInformationThread

x_mitre_methods.definition: (GetLastError); The OutputDebugString function will demonstrate different behavior depending whether or not a debugger is present. See [[7]](#7) for details.
x_mitre_methods.name: OutputDebugString

x_mitre_methods.definition: (Explorer.exe); Executing an application by a debugger will result in the parent process being the debugger process rather than the shell process (Explorer.exe) or the command line. Malware checks its parent process; if it's not explorer.exe, it's assumed to be a debugger. [[7]](#7)
x_mitre_methods.name: Parent Process

x_mitre_methods.definition: The Process Environment Block (PEB) is a Windows data structure associated with each process that contains several fields, such as "BeingDebugged," "NtGlobalFlag," and "IsDebugged". Testing the value of this PEB field of a particular process can indicate whether the process is being debugged. Testing "BeingDebugged" is equivalent to using the kernel32!IsDebuggerPresent API call (see next method).
x_mitre_methods.name: Process Environment Block

x_mitre_methods.definition: Process heaps are affected by debuggers. Malware can detect a debugger by checking heap header fields such as Flags (debugger present if value greater than 2) or ForceFlags (debugger present if value greater than 0).
x_mitre_methods.name: ProcessHeap

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may call RtlAdjustPrivilege to detect if a debugger is attached (or to prevent a debugger from attaching).
x_mitre_methods.name: RtlAdjustPrivilege

x_mitre_methods.definition: (Csrss.exe); Using the OpenProcess function on the csrss.exe process can detect a debugger. [[7]](#7)
x_mitre_methods.name: SeDebugPrivilege

x_mitre_methods.definition: (Protected Handle);
x_mitre_methods.name: SetHandleInformation

x_mitre_methods.definition: (INT3/0xCC)
x_mitre_methods.name: Software Breakpoints

x_mitre_methods.definition: Similar to the anti-exploitation method of the same name, malware may try to detect mucking with values on the stack.
x_mitre_methods.name: Stack Canary

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may access information in the Thread Information Block (TIB) for debug detection or process obfuscation detection. The TIB can be accessed as an offset of the segment register (e.g., fs:[20h]).
x_mitre_methods.name: TIB Aware

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware may compare time between two points to detect unusual execution, such as the (relative) massive delays introduced by debugging.
x_mitre_methods.name: Timing/Delay Checks

x_mitre_methods.definition: The UnhandledExceptionFilter function is called if no registered exception handlers exist, but it will not be reached if a debugger is present. See [[7]](#7) for details.
x_mitre_methods.name: UnhandledExceptionFilter

x_mitre_methods.definition: WudfIsAnyDebuggerPresent, WudfIsKernelDebuggerPresent, WudfIsUserDebuggerPresent
x_mitre_methods.name: WudfIsAnyDebuggerPresent

objects.name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
objects.description: Malware may use a standard application layer protocol (e.g., HTTP) to blend with usual traffic.

objects.name: Credential Dumping
objects.description: Malware may obtain account login and password information.

objects.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to find details about the system's network configuration.

objects.name: Screen Capture
objects.description: Malware takes screen captures.

objects.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
objects.description: Malware may exploit a software vulnerability to escalate privileges.

objects.name: Email Collection
objects.description: Malware targets user email for collection.

objects.name: Data from Network Shared Drive
objects.description: Malware collects from remote systems via shared network drives that are accessible from the compromised system.

objects.name: Fallback Channels
objects.description: Malware may contain a secondary command and control server or may communicate over a backup channel.

objects.name: Scheduled Task
objects.description: Malware may use the Windows Task Scheduler to schedule programs or scripts to be executed at a date and time.

objects.name: AppInit DLLs
objects.description: Malware may abuse DLLs specified in the registry AppInit_DLLs value to load and run malicious DLLs.

objects.name: Startup Items
objects.description: Malware may add an entry to the macOS StartupItems directory to enable persistence. Because StartupItems run during the bootup phase of macOS, they will run as root, enabling privilege escalation.

objects.name: Disassembler Evasion
objects.description: Malware code evades disassembly in a recursive or linear disassembler. Some methods apply to both types of disassemblers; others apply to one type and not the other.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Simple number or string arguments to API calls are calculated at runtime, making linear disassembly more difficult.
x_mitre_methods.name: Argument Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Conditional jumps are sometimes used to confuse disassembly engines, resulting in the wrong instruction boundaries and thus wrong mnemonic and operands; identified by instructions *jmp/jcc to a label+#* (e.g., JNE loc_401345fe+2).
x_mitre_methods.name: Conditional Misdirection

x_mitre_methods.definition: Explicit use of computed values for control flow, often many times in the same basic block or function.
x_mitre_methods.name: Value Dependent Jumps

x_mitre_methods.definition: Variables, often strings, are broken into multiple parts and store out of order, in different memory ranges, or both. They must then be recomposed before use.
x_mitre_methods.name: Variable Recomposition

x_mitre_methods.definition: Typically, VBA source code is compiled into p-code, which is stored with compressed sourced code in the OLE file with VBA macros. VBA Stomping - when the VBA source code is removed and only the p-code remains - makes analysis much harder. See [[3]](#3) for an analysis of a VBA-Stomped malicious VBA Office document. See [[4]](#4) for information on Evil Clippy, a tool that creates malicious MS Office documents.
x_mitre_methods.name: VBA Stomping

objects.name: Hooking
objects.description: Malware alters API behavior or redirects execution to a malicious API version for a variety of purposes. Malware may use hooking to load and execute code within the context of another process, hiding execution and gaining elevated privileges and access to the process's memory. Methods related to anti-behavioral analysis are below. For example, hooking can be used to prevent memory dumps - see also [Memory Dump Obstruction](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/anti-behavioral-analysis/memory-dump-obstruct.md).

x_mitre_methods.definition: Patching this function to always return NULL prevents drivers from getting information about the physical address space layout, preventing memory dumps. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Patch MmGetPhysicalMemoryRanges

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents memory dumps by preventing mapping of memory into the kernel's virtual address space. [[1]](#1)
x_mitre_methods.name: Hook memory mapping APIs

x_mitre_methods.definition: Intercepts and executes designated code in response to events such as messages, keystrokes, and mouse inputs. [[3]](#3)
x_mitre_methods.name: Hook procedures

x_mitre_methods.definition: overwrites the first bytes in an API function to redirect code flow.
x_mitre_methods.name: Inline Hooking

objects.name: Send Poisoned Text Message
objects.description: A malicious attachment is sent via spam SMS or MMS messages. When the user clicks the link, malware is installed.

objects.name: Spamming
objects.description: Malware may use a victim machine to create and send spam.

objects.name: Change Default File Association
objects.description: Malware may change the file association selections (stored in the Windows Registry) to execute arbitrary commands.

objects.name: Firmware Corruption
objects.description: Malware may corrupt the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other system device firmware to render them inoperable or unable to boot.

objects.name: Man in the Browser
objects.description: Malware leverages vulnerabilities and functionality in browser software to change content, modify behavior, and intercept information.

objects.name: Multi-hop Proxy
objects.description: Malware may chain together multiple proxies to disguise the source of malicious C2 traffic.

objects.name: Disk Structure Wipe
objects.description: Disk data structures are corrupted or wiped, making the system unable to boot.

objects.name: Shutdown Event
objects.description: Malware can register the shutdown event triggered by WinLogon to allow a malicious DLL to execute every time the machine shuts down: when the machine is shutdown the malware will be loaded into memory; then it will download the primary malware and reinfect the machine. The malware will also lie dormant during incident reporting processes. To check whether malware has registered for login events, check the registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftWindows NTCurrentVersionWinlogonNotify. If a subkey with any name exists and it has a "shutdown" value then the dll in the "DLLName" key will be launched during the shutdown process.

objects.name: Compromise Data Integrity
objects.description: Data stored on the file system of a compromised system is manipulated to compromise its integrity.

objects.name: Service Execution
objects.description: Malware may execute code via interaction with Windows services (e.g., Service Control Manager).

objects.name: Create Account
objects.description: Malware may create a local system or domain account for persistence.

objects.name: HISTCONTROL
objects.description: Malware may configure this environment variable to hide its activity.

objects.name: Multi-Stage Channels
objects.description: Malware may create multiple stages for command and control, making detection more difficult.

objects.name: Exploit Software
objects.description: Software is exploited - either because of a vulnerability or through its designed features - to gain access for malware. In general, exploitation may be done by a human attacker, but MBC focuses on software exploits implemented in code. Malware-specific details are below.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Use Sysinternals tools for additional command line functionality.
x_mitre_methods.name: Sysinternals

objects.name: Remote Access Tools
objects.description: Malware may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems.

objects.name: Pass the Hash
objects.description: Malware may capture valid password hashes, which are then used for authentication, enabling lateral movement.

objects.name: Replication Through Removable Media
objects.description: Malware may move onto systems, including air-gapped systems, by copying themselves to removable media.

objects.name: Component Object Model Hijacking
objects.description: Malware hijacks a component object model (COM) object to execute itself or other malicious code.

objects.name: Application Window Discovery
objects.description: Malware may try to get a list of open application windows.

objects.name: Analysis Tool Discovery
objects.description: Malware can employ various means to detect whether analysis tools are present or running on the system on which it is executing. Note that analysis tools are used to *analyze* malware whereas security software (see [Security Software Discovery](https://github.com/MBCProject/mbc-markdown/blob/master/discovery/security-sw-discover.md)) aims to *detect/mitigate* malware on a system or network.

x_mitre_methods.definition:
Malware can scan for the process name associated with common analysis tools: 
   * Debuggers: OllyDBG / ImmunityDebugger / WinDbg / IDA Pro
   * SysInternals Suite Tools (Process Explorer / Process Monitor / Regmon / Filemon, TCPView, Autoruns)
   * PCAP Utilities: Wireshark / Dumpcap
   * Process Utilities: ProcessHacker / SysAnalyzer / HookExplorer / SysInspector
   * PE Utilities: ImportREC / PETools / LordPE
   * Sandboxes: Joe Sandbox, etc.
x_mitre_methods.name: Process detection

objects.name: Hidden Window
objects.description: Malware may use a macOS/OS X tag to prevent its application icron from appearing in the Dock to avoid detection.

objects.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
objects.description: Malware may exfiltrate data with protocol different that the main C2 protocol or channel.

objects.name: Call Graph Generation Evasion
objects.description: Malware code evades accurate call graph generation during disassembly. Call graphs are used by malware similarity tools and algorithms ([[1]](#1), [[4]](#4)), as well as for malware detection [[2]](#2).

external_references.description: K. Blokhin, D. Mentis, J. Saxe, "Malware Similarity Identification Using Call Graph Based System Call Subsequence Features," 2013 IEEE 33rd International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops, July 2013.
P. Deshpande, M. Stamp, "Metamorphic Malware Detection Using Function Call Graph Analysis," MIS Review Vol. 21, Nos. 1/2, September(2015)/March(2016).
S. Shang, N. Zheng, J. Xu, M. Xu, H. Zhang, "Detecting Malware Variants via Function-call Graph Similarity," IEEE 2010 5th International Conference on Malicious and Unwanted Software, 2010.

x_mitre_methods.definition: two layer jumping confuses tools plotting call graphs. [[3]](#3)
x_mitre_methods.name: Two-layer Function Return

x_mitre_methods.definition: invokes ntdll.dll functions without using an export table; an encoded translation table on the stack is used instead. [[3]](#3)
x_mitre_methods.name: Invoke NTDLL System Calls via Encoded Table

objects.name: BITS Jobs
objects.description: Malware may abuse Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) to download and/or execute malicious code.

objects.name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
objects.description: Malware may use a standard non-application layer protocol (e.g., ICMP) because such protocols may be less commonly monitored, enabling communication to be hidden.

objects.name: Configuration Modification
objects.description: Malware may install malicious configuration settings or may modify existing configuration settings. This MBC behavior extends the related ATT&CK technique to all platforms and to the Persistence objective.

objects.name: Domain Trust Discovery
objects.description: Malware may attempt to gather information on domain trust relationships that might be used to identify lateral movement opportunities.

objects.name: Port Knocking
objects.description: Malware may hide open ports.

objects.name: AppleScript
objects.description: Malware may use AppleScript for execution or lateral movement.

objects.name: DCShadow
objects.description: Malware may use DCShadow, a method of manipulating Active Directory (AD) data, to register a rogue domain controller, which may be able to inject and replicate changes into the AD infrastructure for any domain object (e.g., credentials and keys).

objects.name: Application Shimming
objects.description: Malware may use Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (application shim) to elevate privileges or install programs.

objects.name: Video Capture
objects.description: Malware captures video recordings.

objects.name: Debugger Evasion
objects.description: Behaviors that make debugging difficult.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Block interrupt (via hooking) 1 and/or 3 to prevent debuggers from working.
x_mitre_methods.name: Block Interrupts

x_mitre_methods.definition: Intentionally clearing software or hardware breakpoints.
x_mitre_methods.name: Break Point Clearing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Move or copy the first bytes / instructions of the original code elsewhere. AKA stolen bytes or code splicing. For example, a packer may incorporate the first few instructions of the original EntryPoint (EP) into its unpacking stub before the tail transition in order to confuse automated unpackers and novice analysts. This can make it harder for rebuilding and may bypass breakpoints if set prematurely.
x_mitre_methods.name: Byte Stealing

x_mitre_methods.definition: Changinging this value during run time can prevent some debuggers from attaching. Also confuses some unpackers and dumpers.
x_mitre_methods.name: Change SizeOfImage

x_mitre_methods.definition: Check that the unpacking code is unmodified. Variation exists where unpacking code is part of the "key" used to unpack, therefore any Software Breakpoints during debugging causes unpacking to completely fail or result in malformed unpacked code.
x_mitre_methods.name: Code Integrity Check

x_mitre_methods.definition: Using exception handling (SEH) to cause flow of program to non-obvious paths.
x_mitre_methods.name: Exception Misdirection

x_mitre_methods.definition: CALL to a POP; finds base of code or data, often the packed version of the code; also used often in obfuscated/packed shellcode.
x_mitre_methods.name: Get Base Indirectly

x_mitre_methods.definition: Encrypt blocks of code individually and decrypt temporarily only upon execution.
x_mitre_methods.name: Guard Pages

x_mitre_methods.definition: modification of interrupt vector or descriptor tables.
x_mitre_methods.name: Hook Interrupt

x_mitre_methods.definition: Add obfuscation between imports calls and APIs.
x_mitre_methods.name: Import Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: variation of static linking where full API code inserted everywhere it would have been called.
x_mitre_methods.name: Inlining

x_mitre_methods.definition: Use SEH or other methods to break out of a loop instead of a conditional jump.
x_mitre_methods.name: Loop Escapes

x_mitre_methods.definition: Instead of unpacking into a pre-defined section/segment (ex: .text) of the binary, use malloc() / VirtualAlloc() to create a new segment. This makes keeping track of memory locations across different runs more difficult, as there is no guarantee that malloc/VirtualAlloc will assign the same address range each time.
x_mitre_methods.name: Malloc Use

x_mitre_methods.definition: Any part of the header is changed or erased.
x_mitre_methods.name: Modify PE Header

x_mitre_methods.definition: int3 with code replacement table; debugs itself.
x_mitre_methods.name: Nanomites

x_mitre_methods.definition: LoadLibrary API calls or direct access of kernel32 via PEB (fs[0]) pointers, used to rebuild IAT or just obfuscate library use.
x_mitre_methods.name: Obfuscate Library Use

x_mitre_methods.definition: Use several parallel threads to make analysis harder.
x_mitre_methods.name: Parallel Threads

x_mitre_methods.definition: Take advantage of pipelining in modern processors to misdirect debugging, emulation, or static analysis tools. An unpacker can assume a certain number of opcodes will be cached and then proceed to overwrite them in memory, causing a debugger/emulator/analyzer to follow different code than is normally executed.
x_mitre_methods.name: Pipeline Misdirection

x_mitre_methods.definition: Prevents debugger from attaching to process or to break until after the code of interest has been executed
x_mitre_methods.name: Pre-Debug

x_mitre_methods.definition: relocate API code in separate buffer (calls dont lead to imported DLLs).
x_mitre_methods.name: Relocate API Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Overwrite the RET address on the stack or the code at the RET address. Variation seen that writes to the start-up code or main module that called the malware's WinMain or DllMain.
x_mitre_methods.name: Return Obfuscation

x_mitre_methods.definition: Calling RtlAdjustPrivilege to either prevent a debugger from attaching or to detect if a debugger is attached.
x_mitre_methods.name: RtlAdjustPrivilege

x_mitre_methods.definition: Some analysis tools cannot handle binaries with misaligned sections.
x_mitre_methods.name: Section Misalignment

x_mitre_methods.definition: Debug itself to prevent another debugger to be attached.
x_mitre_methods.name: Self-Debugging

x_mitre_methods.definition: UnmapViewOfFile() on itself
x_mitre_methods.name: Self-Unmapping

x_mitre_methods.definition: Copy locally the whole content of API code.
x_mitre_methods.name: Static Linking

x_mitre_methods.definition: A variation of "byte stealing" where the first few instructions or bytes of an API are executed in user code, allowing the IAT to point into the middle of an API function. This confuses IAT rebuilders such as ImpRec and Scylla and may bypass breakpoints.
x_mitre_methods.name: Stolen API Code

x_mitre_methods.definition: Erase or corrupt specific file parts to prevent rebuilding (header, packer stub, etc.).
x_mitre_methods.name: Tampering

x_mitre_methods.definition: Setting dwMilliseconds in WaitForSingleObject to a small number will timeout the thread before the analyst can step through and analyze the code executing in the thread. Modifying this via patch, register, or stack to the value `0xFFFFFFFF`, the **INFINITE** constant circumvents this anti-debugging technique.
x_mitre_methods.name: Thread Timeout

x_mitre_methods.definition: The unpacking code relies on use of int 1 or int 3, or it uses the interrupt vector table as part of the decryption "key".
x_mitre_methods.name: Use Interrupts

objects.name: Network Sniffing
objects.description: Malware captures information sent over a wired or wireless connection.

objects.name: Command-Line Interface
objects.description: Malware may use command-line interfaces to execute programs on a system.

objects.name: Capture Evasion
objects.description: Malware has characteristics enabling it to evade capture from the infected system.

x_mitre_methods.definition: Malware is never written to disk (e.g., RAT plugins received from the controller are never written to disk).
x_mitre_methods.name: Memory-only Payload

x_mitre_methods.definition: Decryption key is stored external to the executable or never touches the disk.
x_mitre_methods.name: Encrypted Payloads

x_mitre_methods.definition: Multiple stages of loaders are used with an encoded payload.
x_mitre_methods.name: Multiple Stages of Loaders

objects.name: Audio Capture
